ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Full three-dimensional imaging via ground penetrating radar: assessment in controlled conditions and on field for archaeological prospecting

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: This paper deals with an advanced microwave tomographic approach capable of providing full 3D images of buried targets from scattered field data gathered by means of Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) systems. The approach is based on an approximated model of the scattering phenomenon and it is capable of accounting for the vectorial nature of the interactions occurring between electromagnetic waves and probed materials. Moreover, the Truncated Singular Value Decomposition inversion scheme is exploited to solve the involved linear inverse scattering problem in a stable and accurate way. The advantages offered by the full 3D inversion algorithm with respect to a commonly adopted strategy, which produces 3D images by interpolating 2D reconstructions, are assessed against GPR data gathered in laboratory controlled conditions. Moreover, to provide an example of the full 3D imaging capabilities in on field conditions, we report on a GPR measurement campaign carried out at Grotte dell’Angelo, Pertosa, (SA), Southern Italy, one of the most famous sites of the Cilento and Vallo di Diano geopark.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) is a popular non-invasive diagnostic tool for in situ surveys widely adopted in different applicative frames such as geology, civil engineering, archeology, and so on [1–4].

The physical principle underlining the GPR technology is that, at microwaves, signal-media interactions are mainly sensitive to electromagnetic parameters. Therefore, it is, in principle, possible to provide reliable and accurate images providing information on the geometrical and electromagnetic parameters of a surveyed region by properly processing the electromagnetic scattered field data.

The quantitative imaging is still an open issue due to the fact that microwaves propagation is a complex phenomenon governed by diffraction rules [5]. As a consequence, sophisticated models of the involved scattering phenomena are needed to properly describe the data. This implies that the achievable reconstruction capabilities depend strongly on the adopted mathematical model as well as on the ability to assure a stable and accurate solution of the involved non linear and ill-posed inverse scattering problem [6].

In several applicative contexts, the main goals of the GPR survey are the detection of buried scatterers and a rough estimation of their location and geometrical features [1–4]. Being the reconstruction of the electromagnetic parameters not mandatory, inversion algorithms based on approximated models of the scattering phenomenon represent the preferential choice to process GPR data. As a matter of fact, the use of an approximated scattering model, which allows to linearize the relationship between the scattered field data and the function accounting for the unknown targets, permits to tackle the imaging problem effectively also far beyond the limits of validity of the approximation on which they are based [7–10]. In particular, while preventing the possibility to obtain quantitative information on the dielectric permittivity and electric conductivity of the targets, linear inverse scattering approaches gives well-focused images of the internal structure of the surveyed region providing reliable information on the presence, location and shape of hidden targets [11–14].

In this paper, we adopt an imaging approach exploiting the Born Approximation to describe the scattering phenomenon and schematize the probed soil as a homogeneous medium, whose dielectric permittivity and electric conductivity are known. Accordingly, the incident field and the Green’s function, whose product constitutes the kernel of the linear integral equation relating data and unknown, are expressed in a closed analytical form, which takes into account the vectorial nature of the wave propagation phenomena. Afterwards, the underling inverse scattering problem is solved by using the Truncated Singular Value Decomposition (TSVD) regularization scheme [6].

It must be pointed out that this paper does not intend to provide a novel inverse scattering technique. As a matter of fact, similar inversion schemes have been previously reported in the literature (e.g. see [15] and [16]). Here, the main goal is to demonstrate experimentally the importance of full 3D processing of GPR data to improve the imaging performances.

To pursue this goal, we compare the reconstruction capabilities of two linear imaging approaches. The first one accounts fully for the 3D vectorial nature of the scattering phenomenon and processes the entire data set all at once. The second one relies on the commonly adopted 2D scalar model and yields 3D images from the interpolation of multiple 2D reconstructions. Such an approach will be referred as a pseudo 3D imaging technique. Therefore, experimental tests, concerning the imaging of a buried dielectric object and carried out with a high frequency commercial GPR system, are presented. As it is detailed in the following, these experiments aim at highlighting that the full 3D reconstruction approach yields more accurate and easily interpretable images, especially in the case of week scatterers. A growth of the computational time occurs when the full 3D reconstruction approach is applied but, on average, it amounts to few minutes on a high performance desktop pc.

To further assess the usefulness of the full 3D imaging approach, we also present the results of an on field GPR survey carried out at Grotte dell’Angelo, Pertosa, (SA), Southern Italy. This site, beyond to be a striking nature trail, is of archeological interest since a prehistoric pile dwelling settlement was discovered in the cave at the end of the nineteenth century [17, 18]. Unfortunately, large part of this ruins has been destroyed and the surviving ones are not visible being covered by the river crossing the cave. In this frame, a GPR survey has been recently carried out to infer about the presence of pile dwelling structures in a not previously investigated area.

Section1.Heading: Experimental assessment
Section1.Para: This section concerns experimental tests carried out at the Electromagnetic Diagnostic Laboratory of IREA-CNR. The goal is to demonstrate the advantages in terms of buried objects imaging, which can be achieved when the vectorial nature of the scattering phenomenon is accounted for. As a matter of fact, most commercial GPR data processing software do not implement full 3D tomographic reconstruction algorithms but they process the radargrams collected along each measurement line, i.e., the B-scan, resorting to simplified 2D reconstruction algorithms. Then, pseudo 3D images are achieved by interpolating the corresponding 2D reconstructions. A pseudo 3D reconstruction method based on the TSVD inversion algorithm has been recently proposed in [19].
Here, we compare the reconstruction capabilities of the full 3D inversion approach described in Sect. 2 with those provided by the approach used in [19].

The provided examples corroborate that, as it was expected, the pseudo 3D approach is able to provide reliable information on the shape of the target, provided that the radius of curvature of the target is larger than the probing wavelength. In fact, in this case, the main part of the field scattered by the target lies in the same propagation plane of the incident field. Therefore, the pseudo 3D reconstruction is able to provide an acceptable estimation of the target size also along the
$$x$$
x
direction. Conversely, when the curvature radius of the scatterer is comparable or lower than the probing wavelength, the use of a full 3D imaging approach is needed to provide an accurate shape reconstruction. As a matter of fact, in this case the 2D scalar model provides a too rough description of the scattering phenomenon, since it is not able to account for the off-plane field contribution to the scattering phenomenon. As a consequence, an undesired over-elongation of the target size along the
$$x$$
x
-axis arises. Moreover, since the 2D reconstruction of the scene are obtained by processing data gathered along a single measurement line, the available independent data are not properly exploited.

Section1.Heading: On field assessment: Grotte dell’Angelo on field survey

Section2.Heading: Test site description
Section2.Para: Grotte dell’Angelo in Pertosa is one of the major karstic resurgences of the Alburni massif located in Campania region, Southern Italy. The cave has three kilometers extent and is crossed, for about a third of its length, by an underground river. It is one of the major natural and cultural resources of the Parco Nazionale del Cilento e Vallo di Diano and has a significant economic value for the embedding area, since it is a recognized tourist attraction visited all the year round.

The archaeological significance of Grotte dell’Angelo was inferred at the end of the nineteenth century thanks to the excavation surveys carried out at the entrance of the cavern by the archaeologists Giovanni Patroni and Paolo Carucci [17, 18]. These excavations are dated back at 1898 and allowed the detection and identification of ruins belonging to a pile dwelling structure, as it is shown by the old picture shown in Fig. 6.
Fig. 6
Historic picture of the excavation survey, 1898

Later, due to the construction of a small dam aimed at the hydroelectric exploitation of stream waters as well as to actions devoted to make tourists the cavern, a large portion of the pile dwelling area was destroyed and another part was submerged.

In the cave no further surveys have been performed until the 2009, when the necessity of the dam maintenance required the drastic lowering of the water level, thus allowing a new archaeological campaign. This recent survey assessed that the area covered by pile dwelling was much wider than the hypothesized one [20]. As a matter of fact, ruins were discovered in the inside of the cave, which are almost completely dark and where it is not possible to make any activity without using lighting systems. Radiocarbon analysis performed on wood pilings samples dated the housing unit to the second half of the II millennium ac [20].

The geology and extent of the site, the abundance of previously discovered archaeological ruins and the probable presence of undiscovered features motivated a GPR survey that has been carried out in March 2013.

Section2.Para: In addition, the full 3D imaging approach described in Sect. 2 has been used to provide focused images and, thus, improve the interpretability of the GPR survey results.

This logline is not visible in Fig. 8a due to the limited spatial resolution achievable when the 200 MHz antenna was deployed for the GPR survey. On the other hand, Fig. 8a. shows localized scatterers, which are hidden at a depth ranging from about 2.4 to 3.4 m. Most of these scatterers have a circular shape, as it was expected for wood pillar of the pile dwelling structure. In addition, the location of these circular anomalies is coherent with the geometry of the wood floor appearing in Fig. 6.

Therefore, the comparison of the GPR survey results with previously documented data indicates that the measurement campaign carried out in March 2013 was successful at capturing archaeological features. As a matter of fact, size, distribution and shape of the anomalies, appearing in the depth slices of the full 3D tomographic image obtained by processing the 200 MHz GPR data, are consistent with those of pile dwelling structures retrieved by means of previous excavation surveys carried out in other areas of the cave.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The imaging capabilities of a full 3D linear inverse scattering approach has been assessed experimentally. In particular, the goal of this contribution was to appraise the improvement achievable in term of reconstruction accuracy with respect to pseudo 3D imaging, usually employed in standard GPR data processing tools. Laboratory tests have shown that the full 3D tomographic approach, which is based on a mathematical model accounting for the vectorial nature of the scattering phenomena, allows an improved estimation of the object’s shape and size. These encouraging results have motivated the use of the approach to process GPR data collected in a test case of archeological interest. The outcomes of the microwave tomography enhanced GPR survey support the hypothesis about the presence of pile dwelling structures hosted near the San Michele altar in the Grotte dell’Angelo, Pertosa.
